description: From Middle English prinken (“to wink, signal with the eye”), from prinke, prinche (“a wink, twinkling of the eye, momentary gesture”), from Old English princ (“a wink”). More at pry.

verbs.description: prink (third-person singular simple present prinks, present participle prinking, simple past and past participle prinked)

entries.meaning: (obsolete or dialectal) to give a wink; to wink.

description: Perhaps alteration (due to primp) of prank (“to deck, adorn”), from Middle English pranken (“to trim”), or from Middle Dutch prinken (“to deck for show, parade in fine apparel”) (from pronk (“show, display”) or from Middle Low German prunken (from prank (“display”)).
Cognate with Middle Dutch pronken (“to flaunt”), German Prunk (“a show, parade, splendour”), Danish and Swedish prunk.

entries.meaning: The act of adjusting one's dress or appearance; the act of sprucing oneself up.
examples: “Is my sash right; and does my hair look very bad?” said Meg, as she turned from the glass in Mrs. Gardiner’s dressing-room, after a prolonged prink.

verbs.description: prink (third-person singular simple present prinks, present participle prinking, simple past and past participle prinked)

entries.meaning: To dress finely, primp, preen, spruce up.
examples: […]  by the Mass: You’ll make excellent Wives, Cuckold your Husbands immoderately: You mind nothing but prinking your selves up.

entries.meaning: To strut, put on pompous airs, be pretentious.

verbs.description: prink (third-person singular simple present prinks, present participle prinking, simple past and past participle prinked)
